body:
1: You should have an option to see uncategorized guilds.

2: Political guilds are hidden by default, and while I don't necessarily disagree with this decision (the far-right-ish politics here can be rather off-putting), it's not entirely clear just by looking at /all. Perhaps there should be a short description above the list of categories. "Guilds are sorted into different categories, which are self-selected. You can customize your feed by choosing which categories you want to see. Political guilds are hidden by default."

**Edit**: It looks like political guilds are hidden by default, but not political meme guilds

3: Can there be an "actual all" that shows all guilds except for those that opted out of All for those who are lazy?

4: If uncategorized guilds are hidden by default, it's unfair to guilds that may not fit in any of the categories you have listed. There should be an "Other/Miscellaneous" category.

**Edit**: It seems like there may be custom categorization coming in the future

5: A guild's category (or categories) should be visible to those who are not GMs. Maybe it should be somewhere just below the guild description. Or maybe you should be able to see them by clicking a button in the guild header.

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>
body_html:
1: You should have an option to see uncategorized guilds.

2: Political guilds are hidden by default, and while I don't necessarily disagree with this decision (the far-right-ish politics here can be rather off-putting), it's not entirely clear just by looking at /all. Perhaps there should be a short description above the list of categories. "Guilds are sorted into different categories, which are self-selected. You can customize your feed by choosing which categories you want to see. Political guilds are hidden by default."

Edit: It looks like political guilds are hidden by default, but not political meme guilds

3: Can there be an "actual all" that shows all guilds except for those that opted out of All for those who are lazy?

4: If uncategorized guilds are hidden by default, it's unfair to guilds that may not fit in any of the categories you have listed. There should be an "Other/Miscellaneous" category.

Edit: It seems like there may be custom categorization coming in the future

5: A guild's category (or categories) should be visible to those who are not GMs. Maybe it should be somewhere just below the guild description. Or maybe you should be able to see them by clicking a button in the guild header.

- sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, don't censor my username]

body:
* Arts: Visual/Drawings
* Gaming: Mobile (Also, what would board games/card games/those types of games count as? Hobbies?)
* Lifestyle: Pets
* Politics: Moderate
* Science: Chemistry, Math (even though it's not necessarily a "science")
* Sports: There are tons of sports. If you're limiting it to categories about specific sports, it's going to be hard to choose. Broader categories like "winter sports" would be good.

If you would allow us to choose one of the main categories (like "science" rather than "physics") rather than a subcategory, it would be nice. Or add a subcategory under each main category called "general". Currently, these subcategories don't seem like enough to encompass everything.

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>
body_html:
• Arts: Visual/Drawings
  • Gaming: Mobile (Also, what would board games/card games/those types of games count as? Hobbies?)
  • Lifestyle: Pets
  • Politics: Moderate
  • Science: Chemistry, Math (even though it's not necessarily a "science")
  • Sports: There are tons of sports. If you're limiting it to categories about specific sports, it's going to be hard to choose. Broader categories like "winter sports" would be good.

If you would allow us to choose one of the main categories (like "science" rather than "physics") rather than a subcategory, it would be nice. Or add a subcategory under each main category called "general". Currently, these subcategories don't seem like enough to encompass everything.

- sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, don't censor my username]

post.title: Category Suggestions

body:
So I've got Pokemon that I took over because the original creator abandoned it, and Pokemon being Pokemon...it's a very vast franchise that covers a *lot* of ground.

It's a game franchise that started on handhelds but has spread to consoles, there's movies & tv series & comics; it's one of the single biggest franchises in existence.

So I find myself with the problem of not being able to fit it into the right category without leaving it out of others that it would be equally justified in using.

To a far lesser degree, +Battlebots. I'm able to settle on "TV & Movies" since that's what it *primarily* covers, but there's also the technological side since I've at least ostensibly set it up for discussing robot combat in general, which includes building combat robots, which is very much a techie thing.

Which brings me to the question of "How do you handle the problem of guilds that need more than one label?"

Is it too late to swap the category system over to some other method at a later date? Possibly something that might allow people to insert their own categories and attach multiple categories to guilds?

body:
Is it gonna work like talked about on the ruqqus pinned topic a few months back? I don't think hiding any particular subject is a good thing personally, even if it's not appealing, ideally with categories just showing a few topics from each and with a bunch of non-retarded ategories they'll be drowned out so the front page doesn't look like a waste.

 Copy paste old topic post -

https://ruqqus.com/+Ruqqus/post/2s6n/the-ruqqus-frontpage-your-input-wanted/9ns0

> I'm not sure if it would be possible coding wise, but going with a mix of 1 and 2, how about the front page has like sections or tabs for each thing that has a few posts from a few guilds that have marked themselves as whatever.

I.e

....

**Food**

+Cooking - Yummy food recipes that take 3 mins

+Food - I ate only sausages for two months, here's how it went

+Pizza - Pizza toppings that should be outlawed

....

**Political**

+Politics - Democrats push back on vast right wing conspiracy that Biden crying on stage and calling Trump momma repeatedly is a sign of health issues

+FuckRioters - Rioters stamping man to death while screaming 'Die for being a white male' is not a racist hate crime says DA

+Democrats - Biden's momma speech was a moving and heartfelt commentary on family values - here's why that's important

...

**Music**

+Music - Soundtrack to film

+Piano - 5 techniques to gain hand independence

+musicproduction - How to add beefiness to your kicks in Ableton

....

**Random**

+Documentaries - The worlds most daring bank robbery

+bigchungas - Chunga chunga

+foxes - Looking cute in a green field

..

Maybe then something like :

See all guilds here - LINK

See trending here - LINK

See newest posts here - LINK

.. with text about joining and being able to filter and create your own page.

body: All my qualms: Guilds should be in Trending/All anyways, there are some GMs out there who don't read the new update posts as soon as they come out. Why can we only choose a single subcategory for our guilds? I see how subcategories can be useful for more GM control, but some guilds don't quite match a subcategory while also falling under the main category. Eg +Minecraft falls under Gaming, but it's on both Console and PC. The GM of it should be able to choose Gaming in general. Is there even an opt-in setting for categories? We shouldn't be worrying about categories when users can't choose the categories they want to see. If a person opted into a subcategory of Gaming, would they see guilds corresponding to other subcategories of Gaming? What should the GMs of +Politics, +Technology, +Gaming choose? I think guilds can fall under many subcategories of different main categories. And what should I set my guild +Art to? It should only be the main categories that are required, not sub categories. Finally, flairs are like categorizations in a guild, why are there still no post or user flairs?
body_html: All my qualms: Guilds should be in Trending/All anyways, there are some GMs out there who don't read the new update posts as soon as they come out. Why can we only choose a single subcategory for our guilds? I see how subcategories can be useful for more GM control, but some guilds don't quite match a subcategory while also falling under the main category. Eg +Minecraft falls under Gaming, but it's on both Console and PC. The GM of it should be able to choose Gaming in general. Is there even an opt-in setting for categories? We shouldn't be worrying about categories when users can't choose the categories they want to see. If a person opted into a subcategory of Gaming, would they see guilds corresponding to other subcategories of Gaming? What should the GMs of +Politics, +Technology, +gaming choose? I think guilds can fall under many subcategories of different main categories. And what should I set my guild +Art to? It should only be the main categories that are required, not sub categories. Finally, flairs are like categorizations in a guild, why are there still no post or user flairs?

body:
Four of my last five posts do not show up, because I posted in guilds like +Freemasonry trying to help the newbie guildmaster get his guild more active. My most recent post was actually quite a good one, I expected it to possibly hit "Trending" and score him a few new members based solely off the discussion it might bring.

Ironically, I actually hate the "racist narratives" on Ruqqus and try not to post in these sorts of guilds - but today +WhiteGenocide is getting the benefit of my posts and my browsing it and perhaps offering something to it because of Ruqqus' stupid half-assed policy that if I go browse +The_Peace_Churches and post my thoughts there, nobody will ever see it. So amusingly, they're driving more of us TO those guilds. 

Here's the problem with your dumbshit mandatory-Categorization idea, +tennis adopted it and thus I can get karma and attract discussion if I post there, but +Golf has a barely-active GM and somebody asking for months for it to be replaced but the 12 members there are also inactive...it won't ever grow because even if I post a great story there, it won't be shown on All/Trending, so nobody sees it, nobody joins it, nobody becomes GM of it

If you want it to be "mandatory", just make a dialogue box that will prompt the GM next time they log into the site, and provide them the dropdown menus to choose categories. Don't remove all possible purpose to ordinary users posting in +Iran or +Golf or +Dolphins just because they aren't modded by the right power-mods.

In "extra-Reddity" ways, it doesn't even just try to hide porn or even "hatespeech", it literally just hides things posted to +Golf or +Iran or +Browncoats or +ItsOkayToBeMale because they're run by lackadaisical GMs or don't have GMs...and will never attract GMs, since even if I go post in +Golf to get great conversations going, sharing my own photos, ranking courses, etc...none of you will ever see it on All/Trending and think "oh neat, a golf guild".

It's extra-Reddity because they're just empowering a "super-user" class whose guilds will have value, and 90% of guilds will have no value and be unable to gain value even I make an effort to put some quality posts into them. 

Basically this rule, as it stands, will drastically increase the echo-chamber and reduce us to a few power-guilds while all of the old guilds with fewer than 500 members will not even be worth TRYING to build up unless you ARE the moderator. But if you're not the moderator, and nobody's a super-active mod who is changing settings (what percentage of guilds even have a banner set?) then there's no point even POSTING in it.

At worst, it's outright censorship - at "best" it's an attempt to monetize the site for power-users to dominate the narrative. Either way, it's losing my interest quickly.
body_html:
Four of my last five posts do not show up, because I posted in guilds like +Freemasonry trying to help the newbie guildmaster get his guild more active. My most recent post was actually quite a good one, I expected it to possibly hit "Trending" and score him a few new members based solely off the discussion it might bring.

Ironically, I actually hate the "racist narratives" on Ruqqus and try not to post in these sorts of guilds - but today +WhiteGenocide is getting the benefit of my posts and my browsing it and perhaps offering something to it because of Ruqqus' stupid half-assed policy that if I go browse +The_Peace_Churches and post my thoughts there, nobody will ever see it. So amusingly, they're driving more of us TO those guilds.

Here's the problem with your dumbshit mandatory-Categorization idea, +tennis adopted it and thus I can get karma and attract discussion if I post there, but +Golf has a barely-active GM and somebody asking for months for it to be replaced but the 12 members there are also inactive...it won't ever grow because even if I post a great story there, it won't be shown on All/Trending, so nobody sees it, nobody joins it, nobody becomes GM of it

If you want it to be "mandatory", just make a dialogue box that will prompt the GM next time they log into the site, and provide them the dropdown menus to choose categories. Don't remove all possible purpose to ordinary users posting in +Iran or +Golf or +Dolphins just because they aren't modded by the right power-mods.

In "extra-Reddity" ways, it doesn't even just try to hide porn or even "hatespeech", it literally just hides things posted to +Golf or +Iran or +Browncoats or +ItsOkayToBeMale because they're run by lackadaisical GMs or don't have GMs...and will never attract GMs, since even if I go post in +Golf to get great conversations going, sharing my own photos, ranking courses, etc...none of you will ever see it on All/Trending and think "oh neat, a golf guild".

It's extra-Reddity because they're just empowering a "super-user" class whose guilds will have value, and 90% of guilds will have no value and be unable to gain value even I make an effort to put some quality posts into them.

Basically this rule, as it stands, will drastically increase the echo-chamber and reduce us to a few power-guilds while all of the old guilds with fewer than 500 members will not even be worth TRYING to build up unless you ARE the moderator. But if you're not the moderator, and nobody's a super-active mod who is changing settings (what percentage of guilds even have a banner set?) then there's no point even POSTING in it.

At worst, it's outright censorship - at "best" it's an attempt to monetize the site for power-users to dominate the narrative. Either way, it's losing my interest quickly.

body:
The current gaming categories are too broad in my opinion. Especially for guilds like +Minecraft which have games on PC and console. Perhaps a "Gaming Discussion" category?

I know this will be an unpopular thing to say here on Ruqqus, but I do think there should be a category for LGBT guilds on lifestyle or culture. Maybe a gender/sexual identity category? Also, I second the idea @captainmeta4 had about religion in the culture category.

The current meta category shouldn't be restricted to just "Ruqqus Meta". This makes guilds like +Tomorrow who are circlejerks of a non-ruqqus exclusive community sort of uncategorized.

Speaking of uncategorized, a miscellaneous category could be very helpful for uncategorized guilds.

Overall, this update is cool, but it needs more categories in my opinion.
body_html:
The current gaming categories are too broad in my opinion. Especially for guilds like +Minecraft which have games on PC and console. Perhaps a "Gaming Discussion" category?

I know this will be an unpopular thing to say here on Ruqqus, but I do think there should be a category for LGBT guilds on lifestyle or culture. Maybe a gender/sexual identity category? Also, I second the idea @captainmeta4 had about religion in the culture category.

The current meta category shouldn't be restricted to just "Ruqqus Meta". This makes guilds like +tomorrow who are circlejerks of a non-ruqqus exclusive community sort of uncategorized.

Speaking of uncategorized, a miscellaneous category could be very helpful for uncategorized guilds.

Overall, this update is cool, but it needs more categories in my opinion.

body:
>we call them that for convenience 

That's the entire point of categorizing. 

I wouldn't say Victoria's Secret is pornography, but I wouldn't call it SFW porn either. If you're just wanting to distinguish the differences between artistic nudity and pornography, then the category could be called 18+. Calling it a Porn category would separate the obvious NSFL materials from stuff that is sexually arousing though. I wouldn't necessarily label raunchy storytelling the same way I would a gangbang video on PornHub, but they'd both be considered Porn, because people can note the obvious similarities that separate them from everything else.

body:
This seems like a more straightforward option.

I don't think Activism or Political News belong in there. Most things are politicised and highly polarised now and most news is political, even if it's about topics that shouldn't be.

I think some of the main categories should have been combined, with no sub categories at all to begin with. It's way too specific and unnecessarily complicated and its encouraging people to make more and more niche guilds with barely any members that eventually die - and where no one actually talks to one another.

I've put +TheGreatReset in world news - it's also not showing anywhere on trending guilds that I can see even after pages of seemingly dead guilds.

I'm half asleep. I hope this makes sense.
body_html:
This seems like a more straightforward option.

I don't think Activism or Political News belong in there. Most things are politicised and highly polarised now and most news is political, even if it's about topics that shouldn't be.

I think some of the main categories should have been combined, with no sub categories at all to begin with. It's way too specific and unnecessarily complicated and its encouraging people to make more and more niche guilds with barely any members that eventually die - and where no one actually talks to one another.

I've put +TheGreatReset in world news - it's also not showing anywhere on trending guilds that I can see even after pages of seemingly dead guilds.

I'm half asleep. I hope this makes sense.

post.title: Category Suggestions

body:
I like the sentiment behind solving the problem but I'm not sure if this is the best solution. Maintaining the categories and keeping them accurate and relevant will be really difficult over time. I'm sure you'll get a lot of feedback from members saying they dont like the set of categories to choose from. 

A better idea might be to just let users create categories on their own and put guilds into them which would probably be way more scalable long-term. Then admins dont have to maintain them and guilds wont be pigeon-holed into a single bucket. A lot of guilds fall into multiple categories—not just one—or, over time, grow into a different category than the GM originally intended.
body_html:
I like the sentiment behind solving the problem but I'm not sure if this is the best solution. Maintaining the categories and keeping them accurate and relevant will be really difficult over time. I'm sure you'll get a lot of feedback from members saying they dont like the set of categories to choose from.

A better idea might be to just let users create categories on their own and put guilds into them which would probably be way more scalable long-term. Then admins dont have to maintain them and guilds wont be pigeon-holed into a single bucket. A lot of guilds fall into multiple categories—not just one—or, over time, grow into a different category than the GM originally intended.

body: I may be misunderstanding the reason for this feature but why not just allow users to browse All and Trending by the categories instead of letting users hide them? Hiding content from guilds assumes all content in that guild is of a single category and, if that's not the case, users could miss out on a guild's content they may actually like to see.
body_html: I may be misunderstanding the reason for this feature but why not just allow users to browse All and Trending by the categories instead of letting users hide them? Hiding content from guilds assumes all content in that guild is of a single category and, if that's not the case, users could miss out on a guild's content they may actually like to see.

body:
Need 
-education (for discussing education, not educational content)
-health: general
-arts: written word (for book guilds and creative writing alike)
-lifestyle: values (MGTOW, trad guilds, non-religious morality guilds)
-discussion: community building

We should also have the option to remove the selected category. I accidentally sorted a guild that has no good option into a category, but now it's stuck being sorted into something that doesn't really fit.
body_html:
Need -education (for discussing education, not educational content) -health: general -arts: written word (for book guilds and creative writing alike) -lifestyle: values (MGTOW, trad guilds, non-religious morality guilds) -discussion: community building

We should also have the option to remove the selected category. I accidentally sorted a guild that has no good option into a category, but now it's stuck being sorted into something that doesn't really fit.

body:
I feel like there's "too many" categories that won't really be used? Like "AI" - great - how about just call that technology and the guild name say the rest? How many guilds could possibly use AI?

A couple others that sound great for 10 seconds but might be overkill:

* Fashion vs Beauty
* DIY vs crafts
* Upbeat (news) vs World
* All of the sports ones

Honestly, with the exception of the political ones I feel like all the categories are way too narrow. When the categories are only a few less than the number of active guilds, no filters you can use the categories for will be useful at all.

post.title: Category Suggestions

body:
One thing I'll mention here is my Guild +TechSupport doesn't fit into any of the Technology subcategories. I think there should be an addition of a few more subcategories within technology or the allowance of selecting more than once subcategory within a category as my Guild isn't just exclusive to the Software subcategory, but also to the Hardware subcategory. If I could select both the Software and Hardware subcategories for my Guild then everything would be good.

Another thing I'll mention is about an issue I've noticed of guilds who don't have a category listed will have its posts by members of guilds made less visible in Ruqqus users feeds and to ruqqus users logged out they will not see those posts at all. This is a pity to the members of those guilds who would be posting but unfortunately will not have their posts seen by non-members or those logged out due to the Guildmaster not assigning a category either due to the Guildmaster not logging in since the category implementation, or due to the Guildmaster not knowing, or just that the Guildmaster has not been attentive in general.
A solution to this issue could be for all Guildmasters who have the permission to edit a category to be made aware via notification that the new Category implementation has been implemented, and that in order for their posts to be made visible to the Ruqqus user base, they will need to assign a category for their guild in the guildmaster settings. The notification being the same way a new user would receive their welcome message after signing up.

One thing I think the Ruqqus admins should consider though is that even though the majority of Ruqqus Guildmasters will do the right thing in terms of taking care of their Guild and ensuring that they assign it a category, there will still be the small few who will not be attentive in assigning their Guild(s) a category even if they are notified of the change. Ultimately the visibility of a Guild's posts depend on that Guild's Guldmaster being attentive and assigning a category so maybe someone other that the Guildmaster will need to manually assign a category to these Guilds or maybe the way in which the uncategorised guilds are made less visible on Ruqqus will need to be reconsidered or just tweaked to iron out this problem.

I think though that the new categorization system is a welcome move and something that will be of much benefit, but there are clearly a small few teething issues that need to be ironed out. I have a lot of confidence that you Ruqqus admins and developers will iron out the remaining creases that exist in this implementation. I'm sure you guys are probably aware of these issues already, but I thought I should post this to voice the issues I've been having and seeing with regard to the new category implementation :)

The notification being the same way a new user would receive their welcome message after signing up.
